body: Psychiatric drugs do more harm than good and the use of most antidepressants and dementia drugs could be virtually stopped without causing harm, an expert on clinical trials argues in a leading medical journal.
label: NONCRED
tags: ma charakter anegdoty lub plotki

body: The views expressed in a British Medical Journal debate by Peter Gøtzsche, professor and director of the Nordic Cochrane Centre in Denmark, are strongly opposed by many experts in mental health.
label: NEU

body: However, others say the debate around the use of psychiatric drugs is important and acknowledge that there has been overuse of antipsychotics to quieten aggressive patients with dementia.
label: NONCRED
tags: autor zdania wykazuje braki wiedzy merytorycznej lub nie jest obiektywny

body: Gøtzsche says more than half a million people over the age of 65 die as a result of the use of psychiatric drugs every year in the western world.
label: CRED

body: “Their benefits would need to be colossal to justify this, but they are minimal,” he writes.
label: NONCRED
tags: autor zdania wykazuje braki wiedzy merytorycznej lub nie jest obiektywny

body: He claims that trials carried out with funding from drug companies into the efficacy of psychiatric drugs have almost all been biased, because the patients involved have usually been on other medication first.
label: NONCRED
tags: autor zdania wykazuje braki wiedzy merytorycznej lub nie jest obiektywny

body: They stop their drugs and often experience a withdrawal phase prior to starting the trial drug, which then appears to have a big benefit.
label: NONCRED
tags: autor zdania wykazuje braki wiedzy merytorycznej lub nie jest obiektywny

body: He also claims that deaths from suicide in clinical trials are under-reported.
label: NEU

body: In trials of the modern antidepressants fluoxetine and venlafaxine, says Gøtzsche, it takes only a few extra days for depression in the placebo group – given dummy pills – to lift as much as in the group given the drugs.
label: CRED

body: He argues that there is spontaneous remission of the disease over time.
label: CRED

body: Results from trials of schizophrenia drugs are also disappointing, he argues, and those for ADHD (attention deficit hyperactive disorder) are uncertain.
label: NONCRED
tags: przedawnione informacje

body: “The short-term relief seems to be replaced by long-term harms.
label: NEU

body: Animal studies strongly suggest that these drugs can produce brain damage, which is probably the case for all psychotropic drugs,” he writes.
label: NONCRED
tags: ma charakter anegdoty lub plotki

body: “Given their lack of benefit, I estimate we could stop almost all psychotropic drugs without causing harm – by dropping all antidepressants, ADHD drugs and dementia drugs … and using only a fraction of the antipsychotics and benzodiazepines we currently use.
label: NONCRED
tags: autor zdania wykazuje braki wiedzy merytorycznej lub nie jest obiektywny

body: “This would lead to healthier and more long-lived populations.
label: CRED

body: Because psychotropic drugs are immensely harmful when used long-term, they should almost exclusively be used in acute situations and always with a firm plan for tapering off, which can be difficult for many patients.” In the BMJ discussion, which is a curtain-raiser for the Maudsley debate at King’s College London on Wednesday, Gøtzsche’s views are countered by Allan Young, a professor of mood disorders at King’s College London, and John Crace, a psychiatric patient and Guardian writer.
label: NONCRED
tags: jest niezrozumiałe lub niegramatyczne

body: They argue that the research evidence shows the drugs do work and that they are just as beneficial and effective as medication for other complex conditions.
label: CRED

body: In fact, they are badly needed, they say, because psychiatric conditions are the fifth leading cause of disability worldwide.
label: CRED

body: Many psychiatric patients suffer from other physical conditions, they add, which are a bigger cause of early death than suicide.
label: NONCRED
tags: autor zdania wykazuje braki wiedzy merytorycznej lub nie jest obiektywny

body: They point out that the effects and safety of drugs are monitored and studied in the general population after the research trials have ended.
label: NONCRED
tags: autor zdania wykazuje braki wiedzy merytorycznej lub nie jest obiektywny

body: “Nevertheless, many concerns have been expressed about psychiatric drugs and for some critics the onus often seems to be on the drug needing to prove innocence from causing harm rather than a balanced approach to evaluating the available evidence,” they write.
label: CRED

body: “Whether concerns are genuine or an expression of prejudice is not clear, but over time many concerns have been found to be overinflated.”  They cite the example of lithium, now thought to have less severe side-effects than once feared, and clozapine, an atypical antipsychotic.
label: CRED

body: Clozapine was thought to have increased patients’ risk of death, but recent data has been reassuring, they say.
label: NONCRED
tags: autor zdania wykazuje braki wiedzy merytorycznej lub nie jest obiektywny

body: Dementia experts said use of antipsychotics for elderly patients who become difficult to handle had been a problem.
label: CRED

body: “The dangers of long-term use of antipsychotic drugs for symptoms of aggression and agitation in dementia were highlighted in an Alzheimer’s Research UK-funded study in 2009 and since then moves have been made to reduce their use,” said Dr Simon Ridley, of Alzheimer’s Research UK.
label: NONCRED
tags: jest niezrozumiałe lub niegramatyczne

body: But he and Dr Doug Brown, director of research and development at the Alzheimer’s Society, both argued that drugs such as Aricept, specifically developed for people with dementia, had some effect and were needed.
label: CRED

body: Long-term use of schizophrenia drugs appeared to reduce early deaths, but he added: “In practice, there need to be regular reviews of treatments between a patient and their psychiatrist in order to continually weigh up the pros and cons of any treatment.”
label: CRED

body: Written by C. Fookes, BPharm on Sep 10, 2018  If you have high cholesterol, then chances are you have heard of statins.
label: NEU

body: Statins available in the United States include atorvastatin (Lipitor), fluvastatin (Lescol), lovastatin (Altoprev), pitavastatin (Livalo), pravastatin (Pravachol), rosuvastatin (Crestor) and simvastatin (Zocor).
label: CRED

body: Statins are one of the most common medicines prescribed in the U.S., with more than 35 million people taking them.
label: CRED

body: They work on an enzyme that is used by our body to make cholesterol.
label: NONCRED
tags: autor zdania wykazuje braki wiedzy merytorycznej lub nie jest obiektywny

body: Yep, that’s right…our bodies make cholesterol, mostly in the liver, as well as getting it from our diet.
label: CRED

body: That’s because cholesterol is vital for our survival and involved in the formation of bile acids, cells, hormones, and vitamin D. But sometimes our bodies make too much cholesterol and research shows that people with high cholesterol are at higher risk of having heart disease, a heart attack or a stroke.
label: CRED

body: Which is where statins step in.
label: NEU

body: A review of 27 large trials showed that decreasing LDL-cholesterol (often referred to as “bad” cholesterol) levels by 1mmol/L (40mg/dL) reduced the risk of a major vascular event (such as a stroke or a heart attack) by 25% within two years.
label: CRED

body: This benefit increased year on year for the first five years and was more significant in people who had already had at least one previous vascular event.
label: CRED

body: But there are also experts who have challenged these findings.
label: NEU

body: Surveys have also shown that only 32% of people take statins exactly as prescribed by their doctor with many citing side effects as reasons for forgoing the pills on certain days or just not taking them at all.
label: CRED

body: But what are the serious side effects of statins?
label: NONCRED
tags: autor zdania wykazuje braki wiedzy merytorycznej lub nie jest obiektywny

body: Not everybody who takes a statin has side effects, and they tend to be more common in women, seniors, and in people with liver or kidney disease.
label: CRED

body: People who drink large amounts of alcohol or who take other medicines that may interact with statins are also more likely to develop side effects.
label: CRED

body: Statins and Muscle Pain Determining exactly how many people suffer from muscle pain associated with statins is difficult.
label: CRED

body: Reported rates range from 0.3 to 33%; probably due to the different ways muscle pain is described (such as muscle weakness, cramps, or muscle pain) and the fact patients are usually told to “Watch out for muscle problems!”, which tends to lead to an over-reporting of muscle complaints, commonly called the “nocebo” effect.
label: CRED

body: But, yes, statins do cause muscle pain, although the exact way they do this is not completely understood.
label: NONCRED
tags: autor zdania wykazuje braki wiedzy merytorycznej lub nie jest obiektywny

body: Medical professionals estimate the true occurrence of muscle pain is approximately 50-100 out of 10,000 (0.5-1%) people treated over five years.
label: CRED

body: Blood tests can measure for a specific enzyme called creatine kinase, which can suggest the likely cause might be statins, although other conditions (such as a heart attack) can raise creatine kinase levels as well.
label: NEU

body: But if you do develop muscle problems, especially if they are severe enough to make your daily activities difficult, talk with your doctor.
label: CRED

body: On very rare occasions, a life-threatening condition called rhabdomyolysis (rab-doe-my-OL-ih-sis), which is the rapid breakdown of muscle tissue, can occur.
label: CRED

body: Sometimes just changing your statin can resolve the muscle pain; other times a reduction in dosage may be needed.
label: CRED

body: Taking a temporary break from a statin may determine if the statin is to blame for the muscle pain, but do not stop taking your statin without consulting your doctor first.
label: CRED

body: There is no convincing medical evidence that coenzyme Q10 helps with statin-induced muscle pain; however, anecdotally some people have reported benefits and a one-to-two-month trial of the supplement may determine if it helps you.
label: CRED

body: While it is important to keep exercising, try and avoid unaccustomed vigorous exercise.
label: CRED

body: A more gradual approach will lessen the likelihood of muscle pain.
label: CRED

body: Statins and Memory Loss The link between statins and memory loss is controversial.
label: NEU

body: Some large studies have shown no effect, and have implied that statins pose no threat to short-term memory and may, in fact, prevent dementia.
label: CRED

body: Others have found an association between statin use and memory loss and confusion, prompting the FDA to order labeling changes on all statins.
label: NEU

body: One study blamed it on the nocebo effect again, because people are told by their doctor to report any changes in memory when they start a statin.
label: NEU

body: Numerous other reports have attempted to clear up this confusion.
label: NEU

body: A 2018 review concluded that it is possible statins cause both short-term, reversible memory loss in a certain subset of people and protect against the development of dementia.
label: CRED

body: People at higher risk for memory loss include those who are taking higher dosages, with metabolic syndromes, and who are taking lipophilic statins (these are statins that cross into the brain more easily than other statins, and include atorvastatin and simvastatin).
label: NONCRED
tags: cytuje badania wykonane na bardzo małej próbie

body: Changing statins or decreasing the dose may alleviate some of these effects in people who might be experiencing memory loss.
label: CRED

body: Statins and new-onset type 2 diabetes Taking a statin may increase your blood glucose (sugar) levels which can lead to the development of type 2 diabetes.
label: CRED

body: People who take a statin are 25% more likely to develop diabetes than people who don’t take statins, with the risk increasing the more risk factors for diabetes you have, independent of statin dosage.
label: NONCRED
tags: autor zdania wykazuje braki wiedzy merytorycznej lub nie jest obiektywny

body: However, experts consider that the risk of this possible side effect is worth it; the Jupiter trial concluded that 134 cardiovascular events were prevented by statin use for every 54 new cases of diabetes diagnosed.
label: CRED

body: Many of the risk factors for diabetes can be reduced, such as losing weight if you are overweight, keeping your blood pressure under control, and increasing your physical activity.
label: CRED

body: Statins and Grapefruit juice Grapefruit juice increases blood levels of atorvastatin, lovastatin, and simvastatin, which actually increases the effectiveness of these drugs, but may also increase the risk of side effects, although the actual increased risk of rhabdomyolysis is minimal.
label: CRED

body: The manufacturer’s advice is to avoid drinking grapefruit juice while taking these statins.
label: CRED

body: There has recently been a lot of discussion in the news about the potential hazards of taking antidepressants while pregnant.
label: CRED

body: Some researchers are concerned that they increase the risk of birth defects.
label: CRED

body: Proponents of antidepressants point out, correctly, that depression during pregnancy is also risky and can lead to premature delivery and other complications.
label: CRED

body: Health care providers often make treatment decisions by balancing the risks and benefits of a medication.
label: CRED

body: There are several antidepressants that can be used during pregnancy and lactation, but with some risks of side effects.
label: CRED

body: However, the risk of medication use must be weighed against the risk of ongoing, untreated depression for both mother and child, and the risks associated with not breastfeeding.
label: CRED

body: (See Non-Drug Treatments for Depression) Below is a brief summary of research regarding how medication transfers to infants during pregnancy and lactation, and its impact on infants.
label: CRED

body: Transfer of Medications to the Infant in Pregnant and Breastfeeding Women Medications mothers take are transferred to their infants differently depending on whether mothers take them while pregnant or while breastfeeding.
label: CRED

body: This is a summary of a much-larger literature on selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) use in pregnancy and postpartum.
label: NEU

body: But it provides a starting place for understanding what we know about medication use in pregnant and postpartum women.
label: NEU

body: In Utero Exposure.
label: CRED

body: During pregnancy, medications transfer to babies via the placenta and amniotic fluid.
label: CRED

body: The amount transferred via the placenta is significant and can equal the mother’s dose.
label: CRED

body: But medications differ in terms of how much they transfer, and using a medication that transfers in smaller amounts is one strategy for selecting a medication to use during pregnancy.
label: CRED

body: For example, in a study of 38 pregnant women who were taking SSRIs, antidepressant and metabolite concentrations were found in 87% of umbilical cord samples.
label: CRED

body: The mean serum ratios ranged from 0.29 to 0.89.
label: CRED

body: The lowest ratios were for sertraline (Zoloft) and paroxetine (Paxil), and the highest for citalopram (Celexa) and fluoxetine (Prozac).1 With regards to SSRIs causing birth defects if administered during pregnancy, the Sloane Epidemiology Center Birth Defects Study recently confirmed that that the overall risk of having a child affected by SSRI use was only 0.2%.2 They did note increased risk of three birth defects with SSRI use in the first trimester: omphalocele and septal defects with sertraline, and the heart defect right ventricular outflow tract obstruction with paroxetine.
label: CRED

body: But only 2% to 5% of infants with these defects were exposed to SSRIs.
label: NEU

body: In neonates, third-trimester exposure can lead to “discontinuation” syndrome due to SSRI withdrawal.
label: CRED

body: Discontinuation syndrome includes acrocynaosis, tachypnea, temperature instability, irritability, and elevated drug levels.3 Fortunately, these symptoms are generally mild and self-limiting, and can be managed with supportive care.
label: CRED

body: Severe symptoms are rare, and no reported neonatal deaths have occurred that are attributable to in utero SSRI exposure.
label: CRED

body: Discontinuation syndrome can be distressing to both mothers and babies, but the symptoms are self-limiting, last for 24 to 48 hours, and do not require further treatment.
label: CRED

body: Exposure via Breast Milk.
label: CRED

body: Infants can also be exposed to maternal medications via breast milk, but the amount of exposure is substantially less than in utero exposure.
label: CRED

body: Some medications are better than others in terms of amount of exposure the infant receives.
label: CRED

body: A recent meta-analysis of 67 studies of antidepressant levels in breastfeeding infants pooled data from 337 research cases, including 238 infants.4 The researchers had access to data on 15 different antidepressants and their major metabolites.
label: CRED

body: They found that antidepressants were detectable in the breast milk for all the antidepressants they studied.
label: CRED

body: Fluoxetine produced the highest proportion of elevated infant levels and the highest mean infant level.4 Citalopram was also relatively high.
label: CRED

body: Only one infant across studies had an elevated paroxetine level, and that infant had also been exposed prenatally.
label: CRED

body: All other infant paroxetine levels were zero, and this included three infants with prenatal exposure.
label: NONCRED
tags: autor zdania wykazuje braki wiedzy merytorycznej lub nie jest obiektywny

body: Maternal dose was highly correlated with infant plasma level for citalopram.
label: CRED

body: The correlation was weak for sertraline.
label: NONCRED
tags: autor zdania wykazuje braki wiedzy merytorycznej lub nie jest obiektywny

body: And maternal dose did not predict infant level for fluoxetine, nortriptyline, or paroxetine.
label: CRED

body: Compared with other antidepressants, fluoxetine was more likely to accumulate in breastfeeding infants.
label: CRED

body: With regard to long-term effects, the authors noted that low or undetectable infant plasma concentrations alone cannot reassure us that the antidepressant will have no effect on the rapidly developing brain, and whether chronic, low-dose exposure poses a risk.
label: CRED

body: However, they noted that the studies with asymptomatic infants are reassuring.
label: NEU

body: Moreover, they noted that although antenatal exposure differs from exposure via breastfeeding, the antenatal data suggests little or no long-term effects on developmental outcomes.
label: CRED

body: They noted that we must factor in whether there was prenatal exposure as that provides a “loading dose” that far exceeds any exposure from breast milk and can thus distort findings regarding exposure via breast milk.4 In summary, they noted that breastfeeding infants’ exposure to paroxetine, sertraline, and nortriptyline are unlikely to have detectable or elevated plasma drug levels.
label: CRED

body: In contrast, infants exposed to fluoxetine had higher medication levels, especially if they had also been exposed prenatally.
label: NONCRED
tags: autor zdania wykazuje braki wiedzy merytorycznej lub nie jest obiektywny

body: Citalopram may lead to elevated levels in some infants, but more data are needed.
label: CRED

body: Although these appear safe for the majority of babies, some adverse effects have been identified through case studies.
label: CRED

body: Therefore, breastfeeding mothers should be advised to watch for any possible signs of adverse reactions including irritability, poor feeding, or uneasy sleep.
label: CRED

body: Premature babies or other with impaired metabolite efficiency should especially be monitored for adverse effects.4   Summary Antidepressant medications are not the only option for treating depression.
label: NONCRED

body: The use of complementary and alternative medicine to diagnose food allergy and intolerance is growing fast.
label: CRED

body: There are many types of ‘tests’ available on the high street and on the internet and it is difficult to know what is reliable and scientifically sound.
label: CRED

body: This fact sheet looks at various tests available and discusses the scientific background or ‘evidence’ behind them.
label: NEU

body: In this fact sheet:     These tests are evidence-based and performed by registered health professionals: A small amount of diluted allergen (suspected protein that person is allergic to) is placed on the skin and the skin is then pricked.
label: CRED

body: If a small swollen lump or ‘weal’ appears, in conjunction with a detailed clinical history, an IgE mediated food allergy may be diagnosed.
label: CRED

body: This test is only performed under medical supervision.
label: NEU

body: A specific IgE test, formally known as Radio Allergo Sorbent Test (RAST) is carried out by measuring the amount of IgE antibodies to a suspect food in the blood.
label: CRED

body: The results are interpreted with a detailed clinical history to give a diagnosis of IgE mediated food allergy.
label: CRED

body: This blood test can be organised by your GP or hospital clinician.
label: NEU

body: There are commercial companies who offer a similar blood test called MAST (Multi-Allergen Screening Test).
label: NONCRED

body: However, as they do not have your detailed clinical history, it is difficult for commercial companies give an accurate diagnosis.

body: Again, this should only be performed under medical supervision where medical facilities and resuscitation equipment are available.

body: The suspected food or foods are excluded for a period of time and symptoms observed and recorded.

body: If symptoms improve then the suspect food is reintroduced.

body: However, too much cholesterol can be a bad thing — which is why it's important to manage it and keep it at reasonable levels.
label: CRED

body: People can check their cholesterol levels by getting a simple blood test.
label: CRED

body: The test measures total cholesterol, HDL (high density lipoprotein), LDL (low density lipoprotein) and triglycerides, another type of fat in the blood stream.
label: CRED

body: HDL is the "good" cholesterol that keeps LDL, the "bad" cholesterol, down, according to the American Heart Association.
label: NONCRED
tags: autor zdania wykazuje braki wiedzy merytorycznej lub nie jest obiektywny

body: Too much LDL cholesterol can cause deposits known as plaque to build up in the blood vessels, which causes a decrease the amount of blood and oxygen going to the heart.
label: CRED

body: This, in turn, can lead to heart disease and heart attack.
label: NEU

body: [Diagram of the Human Circulatory System (Infographic)] When people learn they have high cholesterol, the value often reflects their LDL cholesterol levels, said Dr. Kavita Sharma, the clinical director of The Ohio State University Wexner Medical Center Lipid Clinic.
label: NEU

body: There are really no symptoms of high cholesterol.
label: CRED

body: That's why the National Heart, Lung and Blood Institute at the National Institutes of Health (NIH) recommends getting your cholesterol checked at age 20, and then every five years after that.
label: NEU

body: The doctor will be able to tell if the cholesterol levels have risen too quickly and can help formulate a treatment plan.
label: CRED

body: Bad cholesterol levels that narrow and harden the arteries are exacerbated by a diet rich in saturated fat, being overweight or obese, and having little or no physical activity.
label: CRED

body: Foods high in saturated fats include fatty beef, pork, fried foods, as well as high-fat dairy products, such as milk, butter and cheeses made of high fat, Sharma said.
label: CRED

body: Trans fats, which can also raise LDL cholesterol levels, can be difficult to calculate.
label: CRED

body: Observant eaters can look at nutrition labels to see how many trans fats are in their diet, Sharma said.
label: CRED

body: High cholesterol is also caused, in part, by genetics.
label: CRED

body: For instance, familial hypercholesterolemia, a genetic disorder, happens when the body is unable to remove LDL cholesterol from the blood, according to the NIH.
label: CRED

body: Age and gender are also risk factors.
label: NEU

body: Women generally have lower LDL levels than men before menopause, but after menopause women's cholesterol levels tend to rise, according to the American Heart Association.
label: CRED

body: Smoking and diabetes are also risk factors for high cholesterol, according to the Mayo Clinic.
label: CRED

body: High triglycerides levels are also linked to an increased risk of blood vessel plaque formation and heart disease, Sharma said.
label: CRED

body: They're also linked to diabetes and metabolic syndrome, a condition related to high blood pressure, high blood sugar levels, excess body fat around the waist and high cholesterol levels, according to the Mayo Clinic.
label: CRED

body: A doctor may ask you to fast for 12 hours before taking a cholesterol test.
label: CRED

body: After collecting a blood sample, doctors can measure the different concentrations of total cholesterol, HDL cholesterol, LDL cholesterol and triglycerides.
label: CRED

body: In 2013, the American College of Cardiology and the American Heart Association released new cholesterol guidelines.
label: CRED

body: These new recommendations help doctors determine which people should receive statins.
label: NEU

body: Statins are drugs that block cholesterol production, and may also help the body reabsorb cholesterol that built up in plaques within a person's blood vessels, according to the Mayo Clinic.
label: CRED

body: People in four groups should receive statins, according to the guidelines.
label: CRED

body: These include people who have:   A history of cardiovascular disease..  An LDL cholesterol level of 190 milligrams per deciliter (mg/dL) or higher..
label: NONCRED
tags: autor zdania wykazuje braki wiedzy merytorycznej lub nie jest obiektywny

body: Type 2 diabetes, and are between 40 and 75 years old..  A high risk of heart disease..
label: NEU

body: The last group can be determined using a formula that takes the person's age, sex, race, smoking history and cholesterol levels into account.
label: CRED

body: Healthy LDL cholesterol levels can range from below 100 to about 160 mg/dL, Sharma said.
label: NONCRED

body: Doctors will always recommend lifestyle changes first to treat high cholesterol, such as eating healthy foods, exercising and losing weight.
label: CRED

body: However, there are medications that can help lower cholesterol, too.
label: CRED

body: They include statins that are known under the brand names Lipitor, Lescol, Mevacor, Pravachol, Crestor, Zocor and Livalo, Sharma said.
label: CRED

body: Another type of medication is the bile-acid-binding resin, which includes the brand names Prevalite, Questran, Welchol and Colestid, according to the Mayo Clinic.
label: CRED

body: This medication increases the liver's production of bile acids, thereby reducing the amount of cholesterol in the blood.
label: CRED

body: Studies show that statins are highly effective at lowering cholesterol, but they can cause side effects, such as muscle pain, in some people, Sharma said.
label: CRED

body: In these cases, people can use cholesterol absorption inhibitors, such as the brand name Zetia, which limit the amount of dietary cholesterol that your body absorbs.
label: CRED

body: These inhibitors can also be combined with a statin, such as in the drug Vytorin, which decrease both absorption of and the production of cholesterol, according to the Mayo Clinic.
label: CRED

body: There are also some natural food and supplements that may help to lower cholesterol, according to the Mayo Clinic, including artichokes, barley, garlic, oat bran, beta-sitosterol, blond psyllium (found in Metamucil) and sitostanol.
label: CRED

body: Even beans can help lower bad cholesterol levels, according to a 2014 study in the Canadian Medical Association Journal, as can foods with soluble fiber such as apples, brussel sprouts, pears and prunes, Live Science previously reported.
label: CRED

body: The best way to prevent high cholesterol is the same way to treat high cholesterol — living a healthy lifestyle.
label: CRED

body: By losing weight, eating foods that are low in saturated fats, eliminating trans fats, eating whole grains, fruits, vegetables and fish and drinking alcohol in moderation, it's possible to keep cholesterol and triglycerides levels down, according to Sharma and the American Heart Association.
label: CRED

body: Regular exercise — 30 to 60 minutes a day — and leading a smoke-free lifestyle are also important methods to prevent high cholesterol.
label: CRED

body: Couples trying to conceive may also want to watch their cholesterol levels.
label: CRED

body: According to a 2014 study of about 500 couples, researchers found a strong link between men and women with higher levels of cholesterol and the time it took them to become pregnant, Live Science previously reported.

body: However, it may be unwise to have your cholesterol levels bounce around dramatically like a yo-yo.

body: These two tests are very different in what is tested, the process and the results.A blood test is testing for IgE mediated allergies and will only produce results listing reactions in the immunoglobulin system (these are estimated at only 2% of all allergies)Our hair sample test is examining changes at a cellular level because the latest science shows that up to 43% of allergies are in fact a reaction in T cells.The two tests are measuring totally different reactions and will produce totally different results.

body: Currently the main way of identifying the two types of allergies : IgE and Non IgE is on the reaction time from consuming or being in contact with the item.If you notice a reaction that is almost instant or within 2 hours max , you would normally consult with your GP and he might consider a blood test.These are normally essential for more serious allergies which fortunately only account for 2% of all allergies.If your reaction time is slower or you are unable to identify the link between your symptoms then it is more than likely you have a non IgE mediated allergy.In this instance , we would recommend our hair based non IgE mediated allergy test.

​Now before I talk about this next bit I want to make something clear: 
Generally speaking foremilk and hindmilk is not something you need to worry about!
label: NEU

body: I've been hearing mommas talk alot about foremilk AND hindmilk over the years and there are soooooo many misconceptions.
label: CRED

body: Foremilk and hindmilk are terms coined by researchers.
label: CRED

body: Foremilk describes the milk at the beginning of a feeding, and hindmilk describes the milk at the end of the feeding.
label: CRED

body: They are usually not dramatically different types of milk.
label: CRED

body: HOWEVER, when you have an oversupply of milk, or OALD, the foremilk can be a problem.
label: CRED

body: NOT because the foremilk and hindmilk are dramatically different, but because you have TOO MUCH milk.
label: NEU

body: When you do not have an oversupply, babies are naturally getting a great balance of milk, and there is no need to even put a second thought to foremilk/hindmilk.

body: In the new study, Lugo-Candelas and her colleagues studied the brains of 98 human infants, 16 babies whose mothers were treated for depression with SSRIs during pregnancy, 21 mothers with depression but not treated, and 61 mothers with no history of depression.

body: Seventy five percent of mothers receiving SSRIs were white, educated, and financially stable.

body: A food intolerance is not the same as a food allergy.

body: Here's how to tell the difference.
label: NEU

body: A food allergy: A food allergy: is a reaction by your immune system (your body's defence against infection).
label: CRED

body: Your immune system mistakenly treats proteins found in food as a threat .
label: CRED

body: A food allergy: can trigger allergy symptoms, such as a rash, wheezing and itching, after eating just a small amount of the food (these symptoms usually happen quickly).
label: CRED

body: A food allergy: is often to particular foods.
label: CRED

body: Common food allergies in adults include fish and shellfish and nut allergies.
label: CRED

body: Common food allergies in children include milk, eggs, fish, peanuts and other nuts  .
label: CRED

body: A food allergy: can be life-threatening.
label: CRED

body: A food intolerance: A food intolerance: does not involve your immune system – there is no allergic reaction, and it is never life-threatening .
label: CRED

body: A food intolerance: causes symptoms that happen gradually, often a few hours after eating the problem food .
label: CRED

body: A food intolerance: only results in symptoms if you eat a substantial amount of the food (unlike an allergy, where just traces can trigger a reaction) .
label: CRED

body: A food intolerance: can be caused by many different foods.
label: CRED

body: Find out more about diagnosis of food allergies.
label: CRED

body: It is often unclear why a person is sensitive to certain foods.
label: CRED

body: If your symptoms happen after eating dairy products, it's possible you may have lactose intolerance.
label: CRED

body: This means your body cannot digest lactose, a natural sugar found in milk, yoghurt and soft cheeses.
label: CRED

body: A GP can usually diagnose lactose intolerance by looking at your symptoms and medical history.

label: CRED

body: On a similar note, Canadian researchers found that those in the lowest quarter of total cholesterol concentration had more than six times the risk of committing suicide as did those in the highest quarter.4 Dozens of studies also support a connection between low or lowered cholesterol levels and violent behavior, through this same pathway: lowered cholesterol levels may lead to lowered brain serotonin activity, which may, in turn, lead to increased violence and aggression.5 And one meta-analysis of over 41,000 patient records found that people who take statin drugs to lower their cholesterol as much as possible may have a higher risk of cancer,6,7 while other studies have linked low cholesterol to Parkinson's disease.

body: Muscle pain and weakness, a condition called rhabdomyolysis, is actually the most common side effect of statin drugs, which is thought to occur because statins activate the atrogin-1 gene, which plays a key role in muscle atrophy.13 By the way, muscle pain and weakness may be an indication that your body tissues are actually breaking down — a condition that can cause kidney damage.

body: NNT answers the question: How many people have to take a particular drug to avoid one incidence of a medical issue (such as a heart attack)?

body: For example, if a drug had an NNT of 50 for heart attacks, then 50 people have to take the drug in order to prevent one heart attack.

body: How can you trust a group that established Teen Screen, a national program to help prevent teenage suicides — despite the fact, by the way, that teenage suicide statistics have actually been significantly down these last few years – and that program ended up actually being the cause for more, not fewer, teenage deaths by suicide?

body: It turns out that by giving teens a diagnostic test (that the developer himself says gives wrong indications 84 percent of the time) and sending supposedly “at risk” teens to counseling, the idea of suicide is more firmly planted in their minds.
label: CRED

body: Then, if they are so “at risk” that they need anti-depressants, it turns out they’re statistically more likely to do themselves in because suicide is itself one of “side effects” of these drugs.

body: What Antioxidants Do in the Body     Antioxidants help to counter the negative effects of free radicals.

body: Foods That Contain Antioxidants Foods High In Antioxidants Increasing antioxidants can be achieved through following a plant-based diet and eating foods such as wholegrains, beans and nuts, as well as plenty of colourful fruit and vegetables like berries, citrus fruits, green leafy vegetables and bell peppers on a regular basis (4).

body: Carrie Fisher’s ashes are in an urn designed to look like a Prozac pill.
label: NEU

body: It’s fitting that in death she continues to be both brash and wryly funny about a treatment for depression.
label: CRED

body: The public grief over Carrie Fisher’s death was not only for an actress who played one of the most iconic roles in film history.
label: CRED

body: It was also for one who spoke with wit and courage about her struggle with mental illness.
label: NEU

body: In a way, the fearless General Leia Organa on screen was not much of an act.
label: CRED

body: Fisher’s bravery, though, was not just in fighting the stigma of her illness, but also in declaring in her memoir “Shockaholic” her voluntary use of a stigmatized treatment: electroconvulsive therapy (ECT), often known as shock treatment.
label: CRED

body: Many critics have portrayed ECT as a form of medical abuse, and depictions in film and television are usually scary.
label: CRED

body: Yet many psychiatrists, and more importantly, patients, consider it to be a safe and effective treatment for severe depression and bipolar disorder.
label: NONCRED
tags: autor zdania wykazuje braki wiedzy merytorycznej lub nie jest obiektywny

body: Few medical treatments have such disparate images.
label: CRED

body: I am a historian of psychiatry, and I have published a book on the history of ECT.
label: NEU

body: I had, like many people, been exposed only to the frightening images of ECT, and I grew interested in the history of the treatment after learning how many clinicians and patients consider it a valuable treatment.
label: CRED

body: My book asks the question: Why has this treatment been so controversial?
label: NEU

body: ECT works by using electricity to induce seizures.
label: CRED

body: This is certainly a counterintuitive way of treating illness.
label: CRED

body: But many medical treatments, such as chemotherapy for cancer, require us to undergo terrible physical experiences for therapeutic purposes.
label: NEU

body: The conflicts over ECT have other sources.
label: NEU

body: ECT was invented in Italy in the late 1930s.
label: CRED

body: Psychiatrists had already discovered that inducing seizures could relieve symptoms of mental illness.
label: NONCRED
tags: ma charakter anegdoty lub plotki

body: Before ECT, this was done with the use of chemicals, usually one called Metrazol.
label: NONCRED
tags: przedawnione informacje

body: A Cleveland psychiatrist who was active then once told me that the doctors and nurses used to chase the patients around the room to get them to take Metrazol.
label: CRED

body: Ironically, given that ECT would become iconic as a frightening treatment, the Italian researchers who proposed using electricity instead were searching for a safer, more humane and less fearsome method of inducing the seizures.
label: NONCRED
tags: ma charakter anegdoty lub plotki

body: Their colleagues, internationally, believed they had succeeded.
label: CRED

body: Within only a few years of its invention, ECT was widely used in mental hospitals all over the world.
label: CRED

body: Many depictions of ECT in film and television have portrayed the therapy as an abusive form of control.
label: CRED

body: Most famous is the film “One Flew Over the Cuckoo’s Nest,” in which an unruly patient is subjected to the procedure as a punishment.
label: CRED

body: There is probably no fictional story that so haunts our consciousness of a medical treatment.
label: NEU

body: “Cuckoo’s Nest,” and many other depictions, are sensational, but we cannot grasp the historical background to the stigma around ECT if we do not acknowledge that “Cuckoo’s Nest,” while released as a movie in 1975, was not completely unrealistic for the era it depicts, the 1950s.
label: CRED

body: ECT was also physically dangerous when first developed.
label: CRED

body: Now there are ways to mitigate those dangers.
label: NEU

body: Current practice, known as modified ECT, uses muscle relaxants to avoid the physical dangers of a seizure and anesthesia to avoid pain from the electricity.
label: CRED

body: These modifications were learned early, but it took a while for them to become standard practice.
label: NEU

body: Ken Kesey, who wrote the original novel of “One Flew Over the Cuckoo’s Nest,” released in 1962, worked in a mental hospital in the 1950s.
label: NEU

body: Kesey, though, would also have known about ECT’s power to relieve symptoms of mental illness, and one of the characters in the book attests to this.
label: NONCRED
tags: ma charakter anegdoty lub plotki

body: At that time, ECT was also used as a “treatment” for homosexuality, then considered by psychiatrists to be an illness.
label: NONCRED
tags: ma charakter anegdoty lub plotki

body: This was not a major part of ECT practice, but this is not a comfort to gay people who received the treatment, for whom it could be traumatizing.
label: CRED

body: The psychiatrists who used ECT in this way sincerely believed they were trying to help sick people, which serves as a warning against “medicalizing” behavior, and assuming that this will reduce stigma.
label: CRED

body: This use of ECT did not last, in part because there was no evidence it did alter anyone’s sexuality.
label: NONCRED
tags: autor zdania wykazuje braki wiedzy merytorycznej lub nie jest obiektywny

body: But it survived in the social memory of the therapy.
label: CRED

body: By the 1960s, the evidence that ECT was very effective for treating depression was robust.
label: CRED

body: But there were also good reasons for patients to fear ECT.
label: CRED

body: These reasons, combined with widespread revolts against authority and conformity that flourished in the 1960s, also gave rise to a revolt against medical authority – the anti-psychiatry movement.
label: CRED

body: In its most extreme versions, the anti-psychiatry movement rejected the very idea of mental illness.
label: CRED

body: But physical treatments, and most especially ECT, aroused its strongest rejections.

body: Most advocates of anti-psychiatry – even those who questioned the very reality of mental illness – were supportive of talk therapy.
label: CRED

body: This provides another clue about why ECT occasions such deep divides.

body: By acting so directly on the body, without any delving into the life history of the patient, ECT’s powerful effects raise questions about what mental illness is, and what kind of psychiatry is best.

body: ECT use declined in the 1960s and 1970s, but revived starting in the early 1980s.
label: NEU

body: During the years since, there have been a growing number of positive portrayals, often in patient memoirs like Fisher’s.
label: NEU

body: Increasingly, ECT came to be provided with consent, and the use of modified ECT became standard.
label: CRED

body: Now, psychiatrists estimate that about 100,000 Americans receive ECT.
label: CRED

body: That is hard to square with a stereotyped view of ECT as a form of abusive social control.
label: CRED

body: ECT continues to have many critics, often people who received the treatment unwillingly, or who felt pressured into receiving it.
label: CRED

body: For example, Wendy Funk wrote about this in her book “What Difference Does it Make?” The main source of continuing controversy concerns a possible adverse effect: memory loss.
label: CRED

body: There is no question that ECT causes some memory loss, particularly of events near the time of the treatment.
label: NONCRED

body: These memories often return, however.
label: NEU

body: And there is also little doubt that many patients get potent therapeutic results, and many patients say they have little, if any, permanent memory loss.
label: CRED

body: But permanent long-term memory loss does occur, and it is uncertain how common it is.

tags: ma charakter anegdoty lub plotki

body: Many clinicians believe it to be exceedingly rare, based on their experience treating many patients over the years.
label: CRED

body: The scientific studies are not very conclusive, however, and serious and permanent memory loss is everywhere in patient memoirs – not least in those patients who have written positive accounts of ECT’s therapeutic effects.
label: CRED

body: In her book “Shockaholic,” Fisher was emphatic about the power of ECT to reverse stubborn depression, but added, “the truly negative thing about ECT is that it’s incredibly hungry and the only thing it has a taste for is memory.” ECT can be an invaluable treatment for many people.

body: Many providers lament that that it is a stigmatized treatment.

body: Who are we?
label: NEU

body: The Electroconvulsive Therapy Service at UNC is a consultation service in the Department of Psychiatry specializing in evaluations for and treatment with Electroconvulsive Therapy (ECT).
label: CRED

body: The psychiatrist currently treating the patient must make the referral.
label: NEU

body:
Telephone 984-974-2198 (for information & appointments)
Fax 919-962-9729 What is ECT?
label: NEU

body: Stated simply: ECT is the application of a small amount of electricity (electro-) to the human brain to generate a brief grand-mal seizure (convulsive).
label: CRED

body: The procedure (therapy) is done while the person is anesthetized and the muscles are relaxed.
label: CRED

body: Why is ECT used?
label: NEU

body: ECT is the most effective treatment for biological depression and in many cases, the more severe the depression, the more likely it is that ECT will work.
label: CRED

body: Response rates for an uncomplicated depression can be as high as 90%.
label: CRED

body: For refractory depressions (those that haven’t responded to conventional medication treatment), the response rate is still in the 70-80% range in many studies.
label: CRED

body: For depression where the diagnosis is less clear or particularly where there may be a combination of diagnoses, ECT may still be effective against depressive symptoms but the response rate is significantly lower (50-60%) and the response is often less satisfying to the patient.
label: CRED

body: ECT has always been relatively safe.
label: CRED

body: Now that the procedure has evolved (like most other treatments in medicine), we are able to administer the treatments in a way that is not particularly stressful for the patient, making it an increasingly sought after treatment.
label: CRED

body: It’s not clear ‘how’ ECT works exactly, but then it’s not clear how antidepressants work exactly either.
label: NONCRED
tags: autor zdania wykazuje braki wiedzy merytorycznej lub nie jest obiektywny

body: We can measure neurochemical and physiological changes in the brain after a response to ECT, which are similar to the changes seen in patients who respond to antidepressant medications.
label: CRED

body: For example a person’s seizure threshold often rises over the course of treatment, requiring higher dosages of electricity to generate a seizure.
label: CRED

body: ECT does not cure Major Depressive Disorder (MDD) or Bipolar Disorder.
label: NONCRED
tags: autor zdania wykazuje braki wiedzy merytorycznej lub nie jest obiektywny

body: It treats episodes of depression or mania.
label: CRED

body: In other words, a response to ECT does not mean that the person will not get sick again in the future.
label: CRED

body: Serious mood disorders are often relapsing disorders in most people and some preventive strategy is required even after a response to ECT (medicines or maintenance ECT are the two choices usually).
label: CRED

body: It is useful to think about treatment as involving two goals: ‘getting well’ and ‘staying well’.
label: CRED

body: How is ECT done?
label: NEU

body: ECT is a medical procedure that is done in the Outpatient Procedures area at UNC Hospitals utilizing many of the same anesthesiologists and nurse anesthetists who work in the UNC operating rooms.
label: CRED

body: The procedure involves a ‘light’ anesthesia using a short-acting anesthetic agent such as methohexital or propofol.
label: CRED

body: After a patient is put to sleep, his (or her) muscles are paralyzed and oxygen is administered by mask (intubation is rarely required).
label: CRED

body: A small amount of electricity is then used to generate a generalized seizure of about 20-60 seconds duration.
label: CRED

body: The maximum amount of electricity we use is 100 joules, though most patients require much less than this.
label: CRED

body: (Defibrillation is around 300 joules).
label: NEU

body: It is important to realize that a ‘course ‘ of ECT entails a series of treatments given 2-3 times per week until maximal improvement has occurred.
label: CRED

body: ECT is frequently given on an outpatient basis, though at UNC we often start patients as an inpatient.
label: CRED

body: This is especially true for older patients or patients with complicated medical problems so that they may be monitored for any unusual response to ECT, including the extent of memory impairment (if any) or other side effects.
label: CRED

body: (See below.)
label: NEU

body: What are the side effects of ECT?
label: NEU

body: Side effects of ECT can be divided into those due to the anesthesia and those due to the treatment itself.
label: CRED

body: Nausea is sometimes seen as a result of sensitivity to the anesthetic agents used.
label: CRED

body: Muscle aches from the paralytic agents is not uncommon as well.
label: NONCRED
tags: autor zdania wykazuje braki wiedzy merytorycznej lub nie jest obiektywny

body: Post treatment sedation is of course not unexpected.
label: CRED

body: From ECT itself you see some expected cardiovascular changes from the seizure (a sympathetic outflow) that can cause a brief tachycardia (increased heart rate) and/or hypertensive response.
label: CRED

body: Patients often get post-treatment headaches (probably due to vasodilatation).
label: NONCRED
tags: autor zdania wykazuje braki wiedzy merytorycznej lub nie jest obiektywny

body: All of these side effects can usually be successfully managed by medications as necessary.
label: CRED

body: The biggest concern most people have about ECT is the potential for memory loss.
label: CRED

body: It is normal to have some impairment in memory after a seizure.
label: CRED

body: For example, a person may forget what happened right before the seizure (retrograde amnesia) and have trouble remembering what happened in the time period right after waking up (anterograde amnesia).
label: CRED

body: This is to be expected in all persons to some degree and is the same phenomenon seen in individuals with epileptic (grand-mal) seizures.
label: CRED

body: Due to the fact that patients getting ECT may be having 2-3 treatments per week for a number of weeks, this confusion can accumulate over time so that much of the period of time represented by the course of ECT may remain foggy.
label: CRED

body: Fortunately, for most people, these memory problems are time-limited, of minimal significance, can be dealt with by anticipating them ahead of time, and by having additional assistance available if needed during the course of treatment.
label: CRED

body: However, some people have reported more persistent and longer-lasting memory effects, especially regarding personal memory of past events.
label: CRED

body: Right now, it is not possible to predict who will have more severe memory problems, but techniques such as using unilateral placement instead of traditional bilateral placement have been utilized to try to minimize these effects.
label: CRED

body: Finally, it should also be noted that for many individuals memory is reported to be ‘better’ after the acute course of ECT because of resolution of the depression and its effects on concentration.
label: CRED

body: The death rate in ECT is about the same as the death rate for ‘light anesthesia’, which means it’s very rare, and about the same as would occur in other simple procedures such as a colonoscopy.
label: NONCRED
tags: autor zdania wykazuje braki wiedzy merytorycznej lub nie jest obiektywny

body: When deaths do occur, it is usually due to cardiovascular complications.
label: NONCRED
tags: autor zdania wykazuje braki wiedzy merytorycznej lub nie jest obiektywny

body: Certain populations, such as those with serious heart disease, recent stroke or heart attacks, or with brain tumors, are at higher risk of serious medical complications.
label: CRED

body: Much of the consultation work-up is geared towards identifying these high risk situations and mitigating them if ECT is still to be pursued.
label: CRED

body: In some situations, we will not do ECT because of the medical problems.
label: CRED

body: Even so, ECT is remarkably safe even in some of the most seriously medically ill patients who have concurrent depression.
label: CRED

body: ECT is often a life-saving treatment, which has been withheld from many until late in the course of their illness because of the social stigma, not because of the science.
label: CRED

body: It could very well be a first line treatment were it not for the continuing stigma.
label: CRED

body: Future advances in technology promise to improve the treatment further.
label: NEU

body: In fact, with experimental treatments such as repetitive Transcranial Magnetic Stimulation (rTMS) it may soon be possible to induce painless ‘localized’ seizures in the dysfunctional parts of the brain which wouldn’t require the patient to even be asleep!
label: CRED

body: Why does the stigma persist?
label: CRED

body: ECT is often still portrayed in the media in the relatively brutal way it was first done, i.e.
label: CRED

body: without anesthesia.
label: CRED

body: Anesthetic agents are anticonvulsants, and it required an advance in the science of anesthesia before we could anesthetize patients, generate a seizure, and avoid the muscle movement associated with seizures.
label: CRED

body: Unfortunately, people don’t know enough about ECT and so can be swayed by these inaccurate portrayals.
label: CRED

body: Also, ECT began to be used in this country at about the same time we began executing criminals with electricity in the Electric Chair.
label: NONCRED
tags: ma charakter anegdoty lub plotki

body: Ever since, the notion of electricity to the head has been seen as ‘punitive’.
label: NEU

body: In fact, in many media portrayals of ECT over the years, the treatment has been depicted as punishment (One Flew Over the Cuckoo’s Nest for example).
label: CRED

body: Combine this with the lingering stigma of mental illness being the patient’s fault, and you can see why the ECT stigma still persists.
label: NONCRED
tags: przedawnione informacje

body: Bilateral versus Unilateral ECT Refers to the placement of the stimulus electrodes on a patient’s scalp (which directs the current path).
label: CRED

body: In traditional bilateral ECT, the electrodes are placed on the right and left temples, allowing simultaneous stimulation of both sides of the brain.
label: CRED

body: This assures a good quality seizure in the parts of the brain that need to be affected, but also allows electricity to pass over the left-temporal lobe of the brain.
label: CRED

body: This is where most people have their language and memory centers.
label: NEU

body: The effect is to cause (theoretically) more memory problems.
label: CRED

body: Unilateral electrode placement allows both electrodes to be kept on one-side of the brain (the non-dominant side), which avoids having electricity pass directly through the language and memory centers mentioned above.
label: CRED

body: However it requires that the seizure (which will now start on one side of the brain only) to generalize or move across to the other side of the brain.
label: CRED

body: This doesn’t always happen successfully, leading to less treatment effect.
label: CRED

body: Most new ECT patients at UNC will be started on unilateral ECT and switched only if not responding adequately.
label: NEU

body: Bipolar Disorder A type of recurrent mood disorder characterized typically by both manic episodes and depression (See Depression).
label: CRED

body: Some individuals may have primarily manic episodes; others may have mostly depressions with rare manic periods, while others may have mixed symptoms of both mania and depression.
label: CRED

body: Episodes can be infrequent or rapid-cycling (i.e.
label: CRED

body: at least 4 episodes over the last 12 months).
label: CRED

body: Lithium has been the traditional medication used to treat this disorder though many other agents are now available as well.
label: CRED

body: Note that ECT works very well for both mania and depression.
label: CRED

body: ECT – Electroconvulsive Therapy A treatment modality using small amounts of electricity to generate a grand-mal seizure in a patient, in an attempt to treat various psychiatric disorders, especially depression.
label: NONCRED
tags: przedawnione informacje

body: Depression (Major Depressive Disorder) A common psychiatric illness characterized by depressed, irritable or apathetic mood or loss of pleasure (anhedonia) and four or more of the following: changes in sleep and/or appetite, loss of pleasure and/or interest in daily activities, impairment of concentration or memory, low energy, agitation or mental slowing, feelings of worthlessness or excessive guilt, hopelessness, helplessness and/or recurrent suicidal thoughts.
label: CRED

body: Symptoms need to be present for at least 2 weeks and be severe enough to cause some functional impairment.
label: CRED

body: Depression Depression is a medical illness known as a mood disorder, and it is treatable.
label: CRED

body: Clinical depression should not be confused with temporary feelings of sadness (“feeling blue” or “down in the dumps”) that are part of life’s disappointments.
label: CRED

body: Depression lasts longer; is far more severe; impairs work, relationships, physical and other activities; and it includes more than a sad mood.
label: CRED

body: Symptoms include trouble with sleep, appetite, energy and self-esteem.
label: CRED

body: Mania A period of persistently elevated, expansive or irritable mood that lasts for a week of longer and includes at least three of the following (four if irritable mood): inflated self-worth, decreased sleep, racing thoughts or flight of ideas, excessive of pressured speech, hyperactivity, excess pleasure seeking and/or distractibility.
label: CRED

body: Seizure Threshold The energy level at which electricity will induce a seizure.
label: NEU

body: This varies for individuals and is usually higher in males and the elderly.
label: CRED

body: Certain medications and medical conditions can alter a person’s seizure threshold.
label: NONCRED
tags: autor zdania wykazuje braki wiedzy merytorycznej lub nie jest obiektywny

body: The UNC ECT service uses a ‘threshold titration model’ to determine the person’s actual seizure threshold so as to minimize the amount of electricity used for the treatments.
label: CRED

body: Joule The joule (pronounced DJOOL) is the standard unit of energy in electronics and general scientific applications.
label: NEU

body: One joule is the equivalent of one watt of power radiated or dissipated for one second.
label: NEU

body: Defibrillation The arrest of fibrillation of the cardiac muscle (atrial or ventricular) with restoration of the normal rhythm, if successful.
label: CRED

body: Transcranial magnetic stimulation (TMS) TMS is the use of powerful rapidly changing magnetic fields to induce electric potentials in the brain by electromagnetic induction without the need for surgery or external electrodes.
label: CRED

body: TMS was originally developed as a tool in brain research, and has been used to stimulate or suppress brain activity in experiments on human subjects.
label: CRED

body: TMS is currently under study as a treatment for severe depression and auditory hallucinations.
label: NONCRED
tags: jest niezrozumiałe lub niegramatyczne

body: It is particularly interesting as it may provide a viable treatment to certain aspects of drug resistant mental illness, particularly as an alternative to electroconvulsive therapy.
label: CRED

body: Although research in this area is in its infancy, there is now strong evidence that TMS is an effective treatment for both depression and auditory hallucinations, with more symptoms and disorders being researched.
label: CRED

body: Your Cholesterol Subtypes Are Extremely Important The notion that LDL is “bad” and HDL is “good” is completely outdated.

body: Sept. 1, 2011 -- Too many kids are still getting antibiotic prescriptions for colds, viral sore throats, and other illnesses that don't require or respond to antibiotics, a study suggests.
label: CRED

body: The study is published in the CDC's Morbidity and Mortality Weekly Report.
label: NEU

body: Antibiotics are some of the most powerful treatments that doctors can offer.
label: CRED

body: But their overuse can lead to antibiotic resistance and hard-to-treat infections.
label: CRED

body: Researchers examined how often doctors prescribed antibiotics to children aged 14 and younger from 2007 to 2008.
label: CRED

body: They compared these numbers to prescription rates in 1993 to 1994 to see what, if anything, had changed.
label: NEU

body: Researchers focused on five common upper respiratory infections: Many of these infections are caused by viruses, not bacteria.
label: CRED

body: Antibiotics are not helpful in treating viral infections.
label: CRED

body: The number of antibiotic prescriptions for these illnesses went down, but it is still too high.
label: CRED

body: From 2007-2008, pediatricians prescribed an antibiotic during 229 of every 1,000 office visits.
label: CRED

body: This number is 24% lower than in 1993-1994.
label: NEU

body: Fewer doctors were prescribing antibiotics for colds and sore throats in 2007-2008.
label: NONCRED
tags: namowa do szkodliwego działania

body: There was little change in the number of antibiotic prescriptions for ear infections, bronchitis, and sinusitis.
label: CRED

body: Often children with ear infections do not need antibiotics.
label: CRED

body: So why are we still doling out too many antibiotics?
label: CRED

body: "Doctors often feel pressure to prescribe when they are uncertain or they think the parent expects a prescription," study researcher Tarayn Fairlie, MD, says in an email.
label: CRED

body: She is a medical epidemiologist at the CDC in Atlanta.
label: NEU

body: This practice may seem harmless, but it is not, she says.
label: NEU

body: "When a child receives an unnecessary antibiotic it puts them and the people around them at risk for infection with a resistant bacteria, which are often serious and difficult to treat, and may even result in death," Fairlie says.
label: CRED

body: "Antibiotics are also not always harmless medications; they can be associated with serious side effects."
label: CRED

body: These can include allergic reactions and/or diarrhea.
label: CRED

body: Parents should ask what's best for their children instead of asking for a prescription for something that likely won't work and may be harmful.
label: CRED

body: Continued Pediatrician Roberto Posada, MD, knows it can be difficult to send the parent of a sick child home empty-handed.
label: CRED

body: He's an assistant professor of pediatrics at Mount Sinai School of Medicine in New York City.
label: NEU

body: Parents are anxious that their child is sick and frustrated that there is nothing they can do to make him or her feel better.
label: CRED

body: This is compounded by the fact that many over-the-counter cold and flu products can't be used in young children anymore.
label: CRED

body: "Some pediatricians think it's easier to prescribe something and move on.
label: NONCRED

body: And on the parent's side, you expect to come out with a prescription to make your child better," Posada says.

body: CHICAGO — Lipophilic statins may be associated with memory and cognitive deficits in a dose-dependent manner, according to findings reported by University of Toronto researchers and presented at the 2018 Alzheimer’s Association International Conference, July 22-26, 2018 in Chicago, Illinois.
label: CRED

body: The effect of HMG-CoA reductase inhibitors, also known as statins, on memory and cognition remains conflicting.
label: CRED

body: Some literature have shown acute cognitive deficits after starting treatment whereas some have shown preventative effects against dementia with long-term treatment.
label: CRED

body: “These mixed results in the literature may be attributed to a lack of rigorous studies distinguishing between lipophilic, blood-barrier permeable statins from hydrophilic impermeable statins, as well as a lack of objective clinical data acquired using detailed, valid measures,” explained lead author Alex Kai Chan, from the Keenan Research Centre for Biomedical Research, St. Michael’s Hospital, Toronto, Ontario, Canada.
label: NEU

body: Chan and colleagues analyzed data from patients who were seen at the Memory Disorders Clinic at St. Michael’s Hospital between 2012-2017.
label: CRED

body: The control group consisted of patients not taking cholesterol-lowering drugs at time of admission, and the experimental group included adults taking atorvastatin (lipophilic statin) or rosuvastatin (hydrophilic statin) at time of admission.
label: NEU

body: Data from T-tests showed significantly lower Mini-Mental State Examination (MMSE), Montreal Cognitive Assessment (MoCA), and total Behavioural Neurology Assessment (BNA-R) scores in the atorvastatin group vs controls.
label: CRED

body: The mean assessment scores for atorvastatin were 25.17 for MMSE, 19.41 for MoCA, and .7339 for BNA-R compared with 26.64, 21.55, and .7856 for controls, respectively.
label: NEU

body: Also, the atorvastatin group showed significantly lower BNA-R subsection scores regarding memory immediate recall (.5113 vs .5926 [control]), delayed recall (.4114 vs .5136 [control]), and working memory/attention (.7122 vs .7718 [control]).
label: CRED

body: There were no significant differences, however, between the rosuvastatin group and controls in any of the evaluated tests.
label: CRED

body: Additional analyses further showed negative correlations between atorvastatin use and cognitive scores for all sections with significant associations found for delayed recall and visuospatial subsection scores on BNA-R (P <.05).
label: CRED

body: In general, no differences in subjective complaints were seen with any of the group Neuropsychological Impairment Scale (NIS) scores.
label: CRED

body: However, significant negative correlations were specifically observed between atorvastatin doses and Total Indices Circled (TIC), Verbal learning (LV), and Academic Skills (ACD) (P <.05).
label: CRED

body: Given the lack of differences seen via the NIS, the authors suggested that subjective questionnaires may not be a trustworthy method to assess possible statin-associated cognitive deficits.
label: NEU

body: “Findings from this investigation suggest that lipophilic, blood-brain barrier penetrable statins may be associated with deficits in cognition and memory, possibly in a dose-dependent relationship,” concluded Chan.
label: NONCRED

body: "Free radicals are basically nasty little chemicals that go around stealing electrons off other molecules in your body, and that causes damage in the body," said Dr Emma Beckett, molecular nutritionist at the University of Newcastle.

body: This reaction is called oxidation, and much like the oxidation that causes iron to rust or a cut apple to brown, it causes damage.

body: Statins are effective at lowering cholesterol and protecting against a heart attack and stroke, although they may lead to side effects for some people.

body: Doctors often prescribe statins for people with high cholesterol to lower their total cholesterol and reduce their risk of a heart attack or stroke.

body: While statins are highly effective and safe for most people, they have been linked to muscle pain, digestive problems and mental fuzziness in some people who take them and may rarely cause liver damage.

body: Statins include atorvastatin (Lipitor), fluvastatin (Lescol XL), lovastatin (Altoprev), pitavastatin (Livalo), pravastatin (Pravachol), rosuvastatin (Crestor, Ezallor) and simvastatin (Zocor, FloLipid).

body: If you think you're experiencing side effects from statins, don't just stop taking the pills.

body: What are statin side effects?
label: CRED

body: Muscle pain and damage One of the most common complaints of people taking statins is muscle pain.
label: CRED

body: You may feel this pain as a soreness, tiredness or weakness in your muscles.
label: CRED

body: The pain can be a mild discomfort, or it can be severe enough to make your daily activities difficult.
label: CRED

body: However, researchers have found a "nocebo" effect when it comes to perceived muscle pain and statins.
label: CRED

body: A "nocebo" effect means people who have negative expectations about a medication report experiencing the potential side effect at higher rates than the drug should cause.
label: CRED

body: The actual risk of developing muscle pain as a result of taking statins is about 5 percent or less compared with taking a pill that doesn't contain medication (placebo).
label: CRED

body: However, studies have found that nearly 30 percent of people stopped taking the pills because of muscle aches even when they were taking a placebo.
label: NEU

body: A strong predictor you'll experience muscle aches when taking statins could be whether or not you read about the potential side effect.
label: CRED

body: Very rarely, statins can cause life-threatening muscle damage called rhabdomyolysis (rab-doe-my-OL-ih-sis).
label: CRED

body: Rhabdomyolysis can cause severe muscle pain, liver damage, kidney failure and death.
label: CRED

body: The risk of very serious side effects is extremely low, and calculated in a few cases per million people taking statins.
label: CRED

body: Rhabdomyolysis can occur when you take statins in combination with certain drugs or if you take a high dose of statins.
label: CRED

body: Liver damage Occasionally, statin use could cause an increase in the level of enzymes that signal liver inflammation.
label: CRED

body: If the increase is only mild, you can continue to take the drug.
label: CRED

body: Rarely, if the increase is severe, you may need to try a different statin.

body: Although liver problems are rare, your doctor may order a liver enzyme test before or shortly after you begin to take a statin.

body: Increased blood sugar or type 2 diabetes It's possible your blood sugar (blood glucose) level may increase when you take a statin, which may lead to developing type 2 diabetes.

body: The risk is small but important enough that the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) has issued a warning on statin labels regarding blood glucose levels and diabetes.

body: What is it about statins that causes so many people to go crazy?
label: NEU

body: I'm not talking about any pharmacological effect of the drugs.

body: Instead my focus here is on the zealous partisans  --  both against and in support of statins  --  who go off the deep end.
label: NEU

body: Unfortunately this creates the appearance of a vast and empty wasteland of the sane middle ground, like the ocean rushing out in the moments before a tsunami.
label: NEU

body: There's plenty of room for an intelligent debate about both the risks and benefits of statins.
label: NEU

body: But, unfortunately, extreme participants on either side make a thoughtful discussion impossible.
label: CRED

body: Instead, we get a professional wrestling match.
label: NEU

body: The Anti-Statin Lynch Mob I don't want to commit the sin of false equivalency: the biggest offenders are the anti-statinistas.
label: NEU

body: Every time I write a story about a study supporting statins, comments pour in from the anti-statin forces accusing me of being a shill for the statin-industrial complex or of crassly ignoring the drugs' side effects, which range from mild muscle pain to, they allege, instant dementia.
label: NEU

body: These knee-jerk responses are difficult to answer, because they are based on pure emotion, and these critics are not willing to consider facts that don't agree with their predetermined narrative.
label: NONCRED
tags: zawiera argument, który jest bardzo słaby/nieistotny w kontekście omawianego tematu

body: Two important facts are nearly always ignored by these critics.
label: NEU

body: First, although statins were once an enormous source of revenue to the pharmaceutical industry, this is no longer the case.
label: CRED

body: All the major statins are now available in generic formulations.
label: CRED

body: The commercial interests have not entirely disappeared, of course, but it is hard to seriously support a narrative in which financial forces play a big role in the story.
label: NONCRED
tags: autor zdania wykazuje braki wiedzy merytorycznej lub nie jest obiektywny

body: (In fact, as savvy observers know, the financial interests are now aligned against statins, since the real money to be made is in new, very expensive cholesterol drugs like the PCSK9 inhibitors that are more likely to be used when people don't take statins.)
label: NEU

body: Second, although there are many important questions remaining about the side effects of statins, all the data from studies that have carefully explored this issue point in the same general direction: statin side effects are real but they occur at dramatically lower levels than is popularly believed.
label: CRED

body: The studies have not been perfect --  no studies are!
label: NEU

body: --  but are consistent and persuasive.
label: NEU

body: Of course, it's impossible to argue with a personal anecdote from a statin antagonist who insists that he or she has suffered real side effects.

body: The larger perspective is always lost in this type of discussion: anecdote is not data.
label: CRED

body: Unless such people have participated in an n-of-1 placebo-controlled trial (in which they alternatively receive a statin and placebo in a blinded fashion) there is no way to know what their symptoms really mean.

tags: autor zdania wykazuje braki wiedzy merytorycznej lub nie jest obiektywny

body: No one wants to believe that his or her muscle pain isn't real, or is related to other factors (like routine aging, diabetes, obesity, arthritis, or lack of exercise, to name just a few), but the best evidence indicates that the "nocebo" phenomenon, in which reading or hearing about side effects increases the likelihood of complaining about these side effects, is real.

body: (And let's not forget, the entire scientific enterprise is premised on the observation that human beings have a near infinite capacity to deceive themselves.)

body: I want to make an additional point relating to side effects.

body: It's important to recognize that for some side effects, like cognitive impairment, sleep disturbance, sexual dysfunction, and depression, there is virtually no good or convincing evidence.

body: In fact, there's no evidence that this is the case, but there's also no evidence to dismiss all risk.

body: The Blithe Indifference of Statin Supporters   Don't place all the blame on the anti-statin side.

body: Statin supporters generally don't engage in the kind of extreme tactics regularly used by their opponents, but they are guilty of lesser evils and these also deserve to be called out.

A study of 70 intubated children with croup showed that those who received 1 mg/kg prednisolone every 12 hours had a lower re-intubation rate (5% versus 34%), and a shorter median period of intubation (98 hours versus 138 hours) than those who did not.2
 Other work from Australia has compared the efficacy of a single oral dose of 0.3 mg/kg dexamethasone with 0.6 mg/kg and 0.15 mg/kg dexamethasone in 120 children hospitalised with croup and found no difference in outcome.3 Median duration of hospitalisation and croup scores post-treatment for both groups in each trial were similar.
